<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/markets-worst-week-since-financial-crisis?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
So That Just Happened
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="The Earth superimposed on the coronavirus " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80OS9jb3JvbmF2aXJ1c19lYXJ0aC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line at the top: </strong>Markets had their <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/27/dow-futures-fall-100-points-after-another-massive-rout-amid-coronavirus-fears.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">worst week</a> since October 2008. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Back then, we were in the middle of the financial crisis. Now, we have the tightest job market in decades, flush consumers, and strong GDP growth. And COVID-19, an infectious disease that’s made people ill on every continent except Antarctica and killed nearly 3,000.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">We're living through history</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We are in the middle of one of the most severe <a href="https://www.koyfin.com/research/2020/02/28/coronavirus-impact-on-stocks-and-the-market/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stock market declines</a> of the last 90 years. It’s only matched by the declines of the 1930s, 1987, 2001, and 2008. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This week, the S&P fell 11.5%, the Dow more than 12%, and the Nasdaq 10.5%. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And that’s just equities. The bond market is also flashing warning signs about future growth, with the 10-year Treasury yield hitting record lows seemingly every day. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why are markets tanking? </strong>Investors think companies will take <a href="https://apnews.com/e00ddab59017f271fe80abef1baf322f?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">significant financial hits</a> from the coronavirus. As you’ve read in the Brew all week, the outbreak has disrupted logistics networks, hammered tourism, and led to the cancelation of major public events. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Microsoft, Apple, and AB InBev are just a few of the many companies that went out of their way to say coronavirus would hurt sales this quarter.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Another possible explanation for why the drop happened <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-28/before-the-crash-unbridled-optimism-put-the-bull-market-at-risk?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">so quickly</a>: Markets had been on an epic, and likely unsustainable, run.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What happens next? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the markets, who knows. But policymakers have a couple of tools to stem the bleeding—one of which is cutting interest rates to make it cheaper for businesses to borrow money. Yesterday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said, “We will use our tools and act as appropriate to support the economy.” Most anticipate a rate cut sooner rather than later. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>despite all the heavy breathing, we’re still in a bull market. That could end (or not) if the S&P drops to 2,708.92, down 20% from its record high.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TELECOM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/fcc-proposes-fines-major-phone-companies?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
A Change of Pace: Phone Companies Hit With Big Bill
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Wireless tower 5G" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/37/wireless_tower">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><em>Getty/Nora Carol Photography</em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) <a href="https://apnews.com/d49d09cff2c80bc6953c0581b731e8cd?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">proposed fines</a> on the U.S.’ biggest phone companies for allegedly playing hot potato with user data.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The fines total more than $200 million and hit T-Mobile, AT&T, Verizon, and Sprint. The FCC accuses these companies of not taking “reasonable precautions” to safeguard users’ location data from third-parties. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The action follows a string of investigations, including </span><span><a href="https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/nepxbz/i-gave-a-bounty-hunter-300-dollars-located-phone-microbilt-zumigo-tmobile?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this one</a></span><span> from Motherboard, that showed personal location data was ending up in the hands of bounty hunters.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Seven months before that report, all four major carriers </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/8582857aff8146f8ac81d247533b2177/Mobile-carriers-cut-off-flow-of-location-data-to-brokers?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">promised</a></span><span> to stop selling location data to third-party brokers.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That obviously didn’t satisfy the FCC. And what the FCC just did didn’t satisfy other critics:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The FCC dragged its feet and issued penalties that let these companies off easy,” said Sen. Ed Markey (D-MA).</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The FCC’s investigation is a day late and a dollar short,” said Democratic FCC Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>T-Mobile is <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/t-mobile-vows-to-fight-fcc-fines-for-location-sharing-11582921450?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">already planning</a> to fight the fine, and we assume others will follow.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F02%2F28%2Ffcc-proposes-fines-major-phone-companies" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/noncoronavirus-headlines-week?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
ICYMI
</font></a>
</h1>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since we started the Brew, we haven’t seen anything dominate the headlines quite like the coronavirus—outside of Baby Yoda. But the business world continued to spin, and lots of stuff did happen this week that had nothing to do with the virus. Here’s a quick recap:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1. Walmart is reportedly starting a membership program. </strong>It’s called Walmart+, it’s still in stealth mode, and it’s got a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/02/28/walmart-reportedly-starting-membership-program?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">long way to go</a> to catch Amazon Prime’s 100 million members.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2. Rajeev Misra, </strong><span>SoftBank’s top Vision Fund investor, reportedly sabotaged rivals by planting stories in the media and staging a sexual blackmail trap. The WSJ has the </span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/softbanks-rajeev-misra-used-campaign-of-sabotage-to-hobble-internal-rivals-11582743294?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crazy story</a><span>. </span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">3. The online gaming platform Roblox </strong><span>raised $150 million at a ~$4 billion valuation. If you haven’t heard of Roblox, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/02/28/roblox-raises-series-g-4b-valuation?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">get familiar</a>—roughly half of U.S. children ages 9–12 use it. </span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">4. Sen. Bernie Sanders </strong><span>co-sponsored a tax bill that would turn startup employee compensation </span><a href="https://www.axios.com/newsletters/axios-pro-rata-0f71e920-9ee2-4586-8045-1d845a7d1605.html?chunk=0&utm_term=emshare#story0&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">upside down</a><span>.</span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">5. The actor Steven Seagal </strong><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/27/movies/steven-seagal-bitcoiin2gen.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">settled charges</a> from the SEC that he didn’t disclose he was being paid to promote a cryptocurrency.</span></p>

The timeless, classic style of these foot puppies means you can match ‘em with all outfits—winter or summer—whether you’re at work, at the bar, or enjoying the great outdoors.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Pick up a pair of <a href="https://cariuma.com/pages/mb-feb20?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=sponsored+email&utm_campaign=weekly&utm_content=x29Feb20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CARIUMAs</a>, walk a few comfortable miles, and judge yourself to be the coolest cat in town.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LEAP DAY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/oversights-computer-code-can-lead-leap-day-slipups?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Leap Day Coding Lessons
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="coding gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=599 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/46/coding_gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="coding gif" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/46/coding_gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Leap Day coding errors are the computer equivalent of Tien Tsin peppers in your lo mein. If you don’t pick them out, they could come back to haunt you later. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>That’s because more code than you might realize isn’t written to recognize Leap Days, impacting system performance on February 29 and/or December 31.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some companies have gotten this wrong over the years:</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Microsoft: </strong></span><span>In 2012, its Azure cloud computing platform </span><span><a href="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/summary-of-windows-azure-service-disruption-on-feb-29th-2012/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shut down</a></span><span> for over 12 hours because it couldn’t authenticate an internet certificate after misunderstanding the date.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Toys "R" Us: </strong></span><span>As recently as 2008, an error wouldn’t allow parents to register their Leap Day baby's birthday on the toy retailer’s site. That meant Geoffrey the Giraffe </span><span><a href="https://www.leapyearday.com/leap-year-bug?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">skipped sending </a></span><span>any perks. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Sony: </strong></span><span>When the company </span><span><a href="http://www.nbcnews.com/id/35646131/ns/technology_and_science-games/t/leap-year-glitch-fixed-sony-playstation#.XlQgGRNKhTY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">misidentified</a></span><span> 2010 as a Leap Year, PlayStation 3’s internal clock caused widespread connectivity issues, error messages, and 42 Sims’s plumbobs to turn red.</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Leap Day bugs are so common that Microsoft Excel <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/troubleshoot/excel/wrongly-assumes-1900-is-leap-year?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">to this day</a> miscalculates 1900 as a Leap Year (it's not) in order to stay compatible with other erroneous programs. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The effects can go beyond digital</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At midnight on December 31, 1996, some smelting machines in New Zealand <a href="https://catless.ncl.ac.uk/Risks/18.74.html#subj5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stopped</a> doing whatever smelters do, racking up over $1 million in repair costs. And at Germany’s Düsseldorf Airport in 2016, about 1,200 pieces of luggage <a href="https://www.dailysabah.com/business/2016/03/02/dusseldorf-airport-leap-year-paralyzes-baggage-software?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">got stuck</a> thanks to a Leap Year-related computer glitch. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What will happen this year?</strong> Hopefully, nothing. But just in case...Tyler Denk, the Brew's Senior Product Lead, says <a href="https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/is-your-code-ready-for-the-leap-year/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this resource</a> is a good read for anyone who’s worried.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LEAP DAY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/28/leap-years-factor-economy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Economy's Extra Day
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="stock photo of people working " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/48/work">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pexels</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Congratulations! You get an extra planetary carousel ride. Because of Leap Day, you’re spending more, working more, and generally contributing to the economy more. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That also means you could be working an extra day this year. If you’re freelance or hourly, you might be making extra money. If you’re salaried, you probably won't.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>There are some exceptions, like </span><span><a href="https://www.prweek.com/article/1674597/london-agency-pay-staff-leap-year-day-wage?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this London-based PR firm</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But whether or not your employer’s padding your paycheck this year, living an extra 24 hours costs money, unless you watch ants for entertainment and grow peas for protein. But we don’t think Thoreau reads the Brew.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How nations handle that complex accounting: </strong>Some, like the U.S. and U.K., factor February 29 <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2016/02/29/confusion-about-the-economic-value-of-an-extra-day.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">into their GDPs</a>. Others, like China and Japan, include the day as it comes, which can lead to head-scratching numbers the following year (since you're comparing apples to Leap apples). </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>KPMG estimates Australia, which does not “explicitly adjust” for Leap Days, will get a </span><span><a href="https://home.kpmg/au/en/home/media/press-releases/2020/02/leap-year-should-ensure-no-negative-growth-for-march-quarter-20-february-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$5.2 billion boost</a></span><span> to its economy thanks to February 29. That should be enough to keep quarterly GDP out of negative territory.</span>
</li>
</ul>

<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The problem is, there isn’t anybody in it. Chinese bookstores are <a href="http://www.sixthtone.com/news/1005252?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">getting crushed</a> by the coronavirus; the chain OWSpace said earlier this week sales were down more than 80%. In a post that went viral on Chinese social media, it wrote “During this arduous time for everyone, it is our hope that every person and every bookstore will finally walk out from loneliness and embrace the spring.”</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We didn’t plan it, but today’s Saturday Headlines are all framed in the negative. Suppose that fits the vibe of the week.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Anyway, see if you can pick out the fake headline from the three real ones. </p>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Visit the Angolan city where it </span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/E2d2tsgz7iHo4/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hasn’t rained</a></span><span> in 53 years” </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Scientists discover first known animal that </span><span><a href="https://www.livescience.com/first-non-breathing-animal.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doesn't breathe</a></span><span>”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Apple </span><span><a href="https://www.inputmag.com/culture/apple-wont-allow-villains-to-use-its-products-on-screen-says-rian-johnson?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t allow villains</a></span><span> to use its products on screen, says Rian Johnson”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Univision’s new CEO </span><span><a href="https://qz.com/work/1808354/univisions-new-ceo-doesnt-speak-spanish/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=daily-brief&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doesn’t speak Spanish</a></span><span><span>”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
</ol>

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line at the top: \u003c/strong\u003eMarkets had their \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/27/dow-futures-fall-100-points-after-another-massive-rout-amid-coronavirus-fears.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eworst week\u003c/a\u003e since October 2008. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBack then, we were in the middle of the financial crisis. Now, we have the tightest job market in decades, flush consumers, and strong GDP growth. And COVID-19, an infectious disease that’s made people ill on every continent except Antarctica and killed nearly 3,000.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWe're living through history\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe are in the middle of one of the most severe \u003ca href=\"https://www.koyfin.com/research/2020/02/28/coronavirus-impact-on-stocks-and-the-market/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estock market declines\u003c/a\u003e of the last 90 years. It’s only matched by the declines of the 1930s, 1987, 2001, and 2008. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis week, the S\u0026P fell 11.5%, the Dow more than 12%, and the Nasdaq 10.5%. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd that’s just equities. The bond market is also flashing warning signs about future growth, with the 10-year Treasury yield hitting record lows seemingly every day. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy are markets tanking? \u003c/strong\u003eInvestors think companies will take \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/e00ddab59017f271fe80abef1baf322f?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esignificant financial hits\u003c/a\u003e from the coronavirus. As you’ve read in the Brew all week, the outbreak has disrupted logistics networks, hammered tourism, and led to the cancelation of major public events. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMicrosoft, Apple, and AB InBev are just a few of the many companies that went out of their way to say coronavirus would hurt sales this quarter.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnother possible explanation for why the drop happened \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-28/before-the-crash-unbridled-optimism-put-the-bull-market-at-risk?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eso quickly\u003c/a\u003e: Markets had been on an epic, and likely unsustainable, run.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat happens next? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the markets, who knows. But policymakers have a couple of tools to stem the bleeding—one of which is cutting interest rates to make it cheaper for businesses to borrow money. Yesterday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said, “We will use our tools and act as appropriate to support the economy.” Most anticipate a rate cut sooner rather than later. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003edespite all the heavy breathing, we’re still in a bull market. That could end (or not) if the S\u0026P drops to 2,708.92, down 20% from its record high.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nA Change of Pace: Phone Companies Hit With Big Bill\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Wireless tower 5G\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetty/Nora Carol Photography\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/d49d09cff2c80bc6953c0581b731e8cd?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eproposed fines\u003c/a\u003e on the U.S.’ biggest phone companies for allegedly playing hot potato with user data.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe fines total more than $200 million and hit T-Mobile, AT\u0026T, Verizon, and Sprint. The FCC accuses these companies of not taking “reasonable precautions” to safeguard users’ location data from third-parties. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe action follows a string of investigations, including \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/nepxbz/i-gave-a-bounty-hunter-300-dollars-located-phone-microbilt-zumigo-tmobile?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethis one\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e from Motherboard, that showed personal location data was ending up in the hands of bounty hunters.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSeven months before that report, all four major carriers \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/8582857aff8146f8ac81d247533b2177/Mobile-carriers-cut-off-flow-of-location-data-to-brokers?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epromised\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to stop selling location data to third-party brokers.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat obviously didn’t satisfy the FCC. And what the FCC just did didn’t satisfy other critics:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The FCC dragged its feet and issued penalties that let these companies off easy,” said Sen. Ed Markey (D-MA).\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The FCC’s investigation is a day late and a dollar short,” said Democratic FCC Commissioner Jessica Rosenworcel.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eT-Mobile is \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/t-mobile-vows-to-fight-fcc-fines-for-location-sharing-11582921450?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ealready planning\u003c/a\u003e to fight the fine, and we assume others will follow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSince we started the Brew, we haven’t seen anything dominate the headlines quite like the coronavirus—outside of Baby Yoda. But the business world continued to spin, and lots of stuff did happen this week that had nothing to do with the virus. Here’s a quick recap:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1. Walmart is reportedly starting a membership program. \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s called Walmart+, it’s still in stealth mode, and it’s got a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/02/28/walmart-reportedly-starting-membership-program?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elong way to go\u003c/a\u003e to catch Amazon Prime’s 100 million members.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2. Rajeev Misra, \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSoftBank’s top Vision Fund investor, reportedly sabotaged rivals by planting stories in the media and staging a sexual blackmail trap. The WSJ has the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/softbanks-rajeev-misra-used-campaign-of-sabotage-to-hobble-internal-rivals-11582743294?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecrazy story\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e3. The online gaming platform Roblox \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003eraised $150 million at a ~$4 billion valuation. If you haven’t heard of Roblox, \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/02/28/roblox-raises-series-g-4b-valuation?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eget familiar\u003c/a\u003e—roughly half of U.S. children ages 9–12 use it. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e4. Sen. Bernie Sanders \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003eco-sponsored a tax bill that would turn startup employee compensation \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/newsletters/axios-pro-rata-0f71e920-9ee2-4586-8045-1d845a7d1605.html?chunk=0\u0026utm_term=emshare#story0\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eupside down\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e5. style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nLEAP DAY \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nLeap Day Coding Lessons\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"coding gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=599 src=\"https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/46/coding_gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"coding gif\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/46/coding_gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLeap Day coding errors are the computer equivalent of Tien Tsin peppers in your lo mein. If you don’t pick them out, they could come back to haunt you later. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThat’s because more code than you might realize isn’t written to recognize Leap Days, impacting system performance on February 29 and/or December 31.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome companies have gotten this wrong over the years:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMicrosoft: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn 2012, its Azure cloud computing platform \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/summary-of-windows-azure-service-disruption-on-feb-29th-2012/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eshut down\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for over 12 hours because it couldn’t authenticate an internet certificate after misunderstanding the date.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eToys \"R\" Us: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs recently as 2008, an error wouldn’t allow parents to register their Leap Day baby's birthday on the toy retailer’s site. That meant Geoffrey the Giraffe \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.leapyearday.com/leap-year-bug?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eskipped sending \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eany perks. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSony: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen the company \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://www.nbcnews.com/id/35646131/ns/technology_and_science-games/t/leap-year-glitch-fixed-sony-playstation#.XlQgGRNKhTY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emisidentified\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e 2010 as a Leap Year, PlayStation 3’s internal clock caused widespread connectivity issues, error messages, and 42 Sims’s plumbobs to turn red.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLeap Day bugs are so common that Microsoft Excel \u003ca href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/troubleshoot/excel/wrongly-assumes-1900-is-leap-year?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eto this day\u003c/a\u003e miscalculates 1900 as a Leap Year (it's not) in order to stay compatible with other erroneous programs. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe effects can go beyond digital\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt midnight on December 31, 1996, some smelting machines in New Zealand \u003ca href=\"https://catless.ncl.ac.uk/Risks/18.74.html#subj5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estopped\u003c/a\u003e doing whatever smelters do, racking up over $1 million in repair costs. And at Germany’s Düsseldorf Airport in 2016, about 1,200 pieces of luggage \u003ca href=\"https://www.dailysabah.com/business/2016/03/02/dusseldorf-airport-leap-year-paralyzes-baggage-software?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egot stuck\u003c/a\u003e thanks to a Leap Year-related computer glitch. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat will happen this year?\u003c/strong\u003e Hopefully, nothing. But just in case...Tyler Denk, the Brew's Senior Product Lead, says \u003ca href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/blog/is-your-code-ready-for-the-leap-year/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethis resource\u003c/a\u003e is a good read for anyone who’s worried.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F02%2F28%2Foversights-computer-code-can-lead-leap-day-slipups\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/48/work\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePexels\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCongratulations! You get an extra planetary carousel ride. Because of Leap Day, you’re spending more, working more, and generally contributing to the economy more. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat also means you could be working an extra day this year. If you’re freelance or hourly, you might be making extra money. If you’re salaried, you probably won't.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThere are some exceptions, like \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.prweek.com/article/1674597/london-agency-pay-staff-leap-year-day-wage?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethis London-based PR firm\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut whether or not your employer’s padding your paycheck this year, living an extra 24 hours costs money, unless you watch ants for entertainment and grow peas for protein. But we don’t think Thoreau reads the Brew.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow nations handle that complex accounting: \u003c/strong\u003eSome, like the U.S. and U.K., factor February 29 \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2016/02/29/confusion-about-the-economic-value-of-an-extra-day.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einto their GDPs\u003c/a\u003e. Others, like China and Japan, include the day as it comes, which can lead to head-scratching numbers the following year (since you're comparing apples to Leap apples). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eKPMG estimates Australia, which does not “explicitly adjust” for Leap Days, will get a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://home.kpmg/au/en/home/media/press-releases/2020/02/leap-year-should-ensure-no-negative-growth-for-march-quarter-20-february-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$5.2 billion boost\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to its economy thanks to February 29. That should be enough to keep quarterly GDP out of negative territory.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\"
